ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

BILATERAL ISSUES WITH MALAYSIA


    1. Mr Leong Horn Kee asked the Prime Minister if he will give an update on the on-going talks with Malaysia on the various bilateral issues currently under discussion.

    The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Prof. S. Jayakumar) (for the Prime Minister): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Prime Minister has asked me to reply on his behalf.

    Sir, I may start by recalling that after Senior Minister Lee's visit to KL in September 2001, he wrote to Malaysian Prime Minister Dr Mahathir to set out the areas of agreement and issues which had to be resolved.

    On 18th October 2001, Dr Mahathir replied to Senior Minister indicating, among other things, that Malaysia might end the KTM train service in Johor Baru and was re-considering its proposal to build an undersea rail tunnel linking Johor and Singapore and a bridge to replace the Causeway. As this was a departure from their earlier discussion in Kuala Lumpur, Senior Minister Lee wrote to Dr Mahathir on 10th December 2001 to seek clarification. We requested Malaysia to set out its position on the various issues so that there would be a clear framework for the officials, led by the two Foreign Ministers, to meet and discuss the details.

    On 4th March 2002, Dr Mahathir replied to Senior Minister Lee enclosing Malaysia's latest proposals on the various issues, including the price of water. Some of these proposals were completely new and different from what had been discussed during the meetings between Senior Minister Lee and Dr Mahathir and in previous correspondence. Senior Minister Lee replied on 11th March 2002 that Singapore needed some time to study the new Malaysian proposals and their implications.

    On 11th April 2002, Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong wrote to Dr Mahathir to set out

Column: 643

Singapore's responses to the Malaysian proposals. The next step would be for the officials, led by the two Foreign Ministers, to meet in Kuala Lumpur at a mutually agreed date to discuss the details. I have written to my counterpart Foreign Minister Syed Hamid proposing a set of dates for this meeting. I am awaiting his reply.

    As I said in Parliament last September, that is, the previous Parliament, Singapore believes that reaching an agreement with Malaysia on the package of issues would be mutually beneficial to both countries. We are committed to forging a long-term relationship with Malaysia based on mutual respect and sovereign equality to realise the full potential in our bilateral relationship. While I cannot predict the outcome of the negotiations, which I believe will begin soon, let me state that Singapore will continue to take a constructive approach with the aim of finding a `win-win' solution to these bilateral issues.

    Mr Leong Horn Kee (Bishan-Toa Payoh): Sir, may I ask the Minister whether it is possible for him to disclose some main details of the contents of the counter-offer from Malaysia, and also whether it is possible for us to know about Singapore's position, because I think the public is interested in this matter. And if it is not possible, then at least he could let us know what kind of tack we intend to take with regard to Malaysia's request. Because we understand that the offer of price for water is exorbitant.

    Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, I can understand the desire of the Member to obtain the details. But, at the same time, I am sure the Member will appreciate that I would not be able to disclose at this stage the details of those proposals and our response, in that the nature of negotiations, I think, it is premature for us to divulge the details when the first round of discussions has not yet taken place.

    As to the broad approach, let me say that Singapore will naturally want to advance our interest. We have heard the

Column: 644

Prime Minister speak in this Chamber of the position we will take on water, so that we will increasingly distance ourselves away from dependence on water and rely on alternative sources. The issue now is not on broad principles any more. Both sides have to get down to details. And on water, for example, we have to get down on details, such as the amount, the quantum, the mix between raw and treated water, and on pricing. But these will have to be sorted out together with a host of other issues when we first meet.

    Dr Tan Boon Wan (Ang Mo Kio): May I ask the Minister, with this wavering of decisions by the Malaysian side, will this be the last time that these changes will stop? We have to end these changes so that we can come down to some serious discussions and settle these issues.

    Prof. Jayakumar: It will not be possible for me to give a guarantee that there will not be further changes in their approach or changes in their proposals. But as Foreign Ministers, I hope Minister Syed Hamid and I will be able, after so many years, to get down to brass tacks at our first meeting, together with our officials.

    Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong (Non-Constituency Member): Can the Minister give us an update on the progress of the alternative search for water source?

    Prof. Jayakumar: I thought the Prime Minister had already sketched in broad outlines our approach in moving towards developing alternative sources, both in terms of NEWater and desalination. As Foreign Minister, I do not have the details of this, but if he were to file a Question or use the opportunity during the Committee of Supply to direct his request to the appropriate Minister, which will be the Minister for the Environment, I am sure he will get a fuller answer.

    Mr Leong Horn Kee: Sir, I want to ask about water as well, but in a different context. Since the Prime Minister has mentioned that Singapore intends to be self-sufficient in water, especially with NEWater and other water supplies, how

Column: 645

did the Malaysians react so far in their communication with us, ie, whether they have a particular response?

    My second question is in the same line of questioning. The Malaysians had mentioned the disagreement over our reclamation of the shores between Singapore and Malaysia. We said that we want to wait for a third party official communication from Malaysia. So, has there been any communication from the Malaysians on this matter?

    Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Leong Horn Kee asked two questions. The first part of his question was: what was the Malaysians' response to what we have said about developing alternative sources? There has not been any official response because this was a statement made by the Prime Minister. But I am sure the Member as well as other Members would have noted in the media, some of their leaders have made statements to the effect that this is up to Singapore. But there has not been any official response. Whether we will take this up in detail during the first round of discussions is another matter.

    Reclamation is not an issue as part of the package. But since the Member has raised the question, let me recall, first, what we have said in this Chamber - that Malaysia had previously sent us two notes. And these notes were on 28th January and 2nd April. But those first two Notes were confined solely to their claim that our reclamation in the Tuas area had encroached on their territorial waters and jurisdiction, which is not true and we have categorically refuted those claims.

    More recently, Malaysians have sent us a note on 30th April protesting our reclamation works around Tekong and Ubin on broad grounds of trans-boundary environmental impact. But I should say that neither the latest Note nor the two previous Notes in any way contain the detailed facts about their concerns of how the reclamation has affected them. You will recall that Singapore has consistently

Column: 646

said that the Malaysians ought to send us a note itemising their concerns. And this was requested by Deputy Prime Minister when he visited Malaysia in March. The Malaysians have said that they will send us such a note. What we need really is not itemisation of general allegations or broad complaints. What we need are details of how our reclamation has adversely affected them, then only we can reply. We have to-date not received such a note itemising and setting out the details of their concerns. They have said that they will send us that note. Members would have read in the media comments by their leaders that they are preparing such a note and it may take a few months. We await that note. When we receive that note and we have the details of their claims, not broad allegations, we will study them and give a reply.

Column: 646

GENERAL ELECTION


    2. Mr Chiam See Tong asked the Prime Minister whether for the next General Election he is willing to (i) release the report of the Boundaries Review Committee at least six months before the dissolution of Parliament; (ii) limit the number of candidates in a Group Representation Constituency to three or, in any case, to not more than six; (iii) reduce the election deposit from $13,000 to $3,000 for each candidate; (iv) have more than one designated rally site in a single-member constituency; and (v) increase the number of days for campaigning from eight to fourteen days.

    The Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Wong Kan Seng) (for the Prime Minister): Mr Speaker, Sir, electoral boundaries are reviewed from time to time, following population shifts arising from housing developments. It is the practice of every Electoral Boundaries Review Committee to release its report in the form of a White Paper, as soon as it is ready and without undue delay. The date of dissolution of Parliament is not decided by the Electoral Boundaries Review Committee. Parliament is dissolved by the President on the advice of the Prime Minister. In any case, if the new boundaries were to be used, the

Column: 647

Electoral Boundaries Review Committee's Report has to be released before the dissolution of Parliament.

    On the question of number of GRC candidates, the law already limits the number of candidates in a Group Representation Constituency to between three and six. There is no intention to change this now.

    Sir, on the question of electoral deposit, the law specifies that the deposit is 8% of the total allowances payable to an elected Member of Parliament in the preceding year. This is necessary, to confine elections to serious candidates. Reducing the deposit way below an MP's monthly allowance would attract frivolous candidates who would stand for election with no serious hope of getting elected. They would try their luck as there is less to lose, and our election would end up like a lottery and be demeaned.

    Sir, the 8% figure is not something that we conjured out of thin air. There is a basis for this: it is roughly the equivalent of an MP's monthly allowance. Historically, our election deposit has always been pegged to the monthly allowance of an MP. When the deposit was fixed at $500 in 1954, the monthly allowance of a Legislative Assemblyman was $500. The deposit was raised to $1,200 in 1973 and $1,500 in 1978 when the monthly allowance of an MP in 1973 and 1978 was $1,136 and $1,483, respectively.

    Sir, the Parliamentary Elections Act was then amended in 1988 to provide a formula to automatically change the amount of election deposit whenever the MP's allowance is varied, without any need for periodic reviews. Nevertheless, the principle has remained the same, which is that the deposit is pegged at an MP's monthly allowance.

    Any serious candidate should be able to raise this amount. In the recent general election, 35 (including the five disqualified for documentary defects) opposition and independent candidates presented themselves for nomination. This shows that

Column: 648

raising money for the deposit was no deterrent to serious candidates. In any case, practically all candidates can reclaim their election deposit. What they have to do is to poll at least one-eighth of the electoral votes. It should not be difficult for any candidate with a serious platform to secure this minimum.

    Sir, on the question of rally sites, election rally sites are selected by the police, based on law and order considerations as well as the need to avoid causing a nuisance to the residents. As Singapore has become more built-up, it is getting more and more difficult to find many sites suitable to hold election rallies, especially fields and other open areas. We may have no choice but to confine rallies to be held in enclosed areas like sports stadia in future.

    It is also especially difficult to find suitable multiple sites within a single-member constituency because of its smaller geographical size. In time to come, the police may conceivably not be able to find even one rally site within some constituencies. It may then be necessary to zone electoral constituencies and have some of them share the rally sites in the area.

    But on the question of number of days for campaigning, Sir, in 1960, the minimum period of election campaign was set at eight days to bring our legislation more in line with what was current in other parts of the British Commonwealth and in the United Kingdom. It was also because the Elections Department had by then gained sufficient experience and machinery to conduct an election more expeditiously. We have not varied much from this minimum period for the past general elections. Between elections, political parties are free to communicate to the population their political agenda and air their views on national policies. Unlike a large rural country, in a small but highly urbanised country like ours, fully served by roads and public transport, coupled with universal access to all manner of communications media, there is really no need for a more prolonged campaigning period.

Column: 649



    Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Sir, the Minister says that the report of the Electoral Boundaries Review Committee shall be published as soon as it is ready. Between elections, there is a period of about three, four or five years. Why is it that at the last election, the report was only ready one day before Parliament was dissolved? They had plenty of time. Why should they choose to release it one day before the dissolution of Parliament? Perhaps, the Minister could explain.

    As regards the number of members in a GRC, the purpose of a GRC of course is to ensure that there is ethnic representation in Singapore. But I would like to ask the Minister whether or not ethnic PAP candidates are confident if they have only one non-ethnic candidate to hold their hands to get into Parliament. Or do they need two, three, four or five candidates to get them into Parliament. The number of six is more for PAP electoral purposes than to ensure ethnic representation in Singapore. Perhaps, the Minister would like to comment.

    Mr Wong Kan Seng: Sir, I agree that the timing of the publication of the Electoral Boundaries Review Committee Report was rather short. It was an unusual occasion because it was just after September 11 and with the economy in recession, the Government has to deal with urgent issues facing us. The Electoral Boundaries Review Committee took quite a short time - I would say about three or four weeks - to complete its report, although the officers might have done some work resulting from the changes in the population as well as the shift in the voters. Immediately after the report was ready, it was published. The Prime Minister then decided that it was necessary to go to the people to have a mandate to deal with very urgent problems confronting the country and we found out that, indeed, the decision was a correct one.

    Mr Chiam asked why do we need three, four or five non-minority candidates to be in the GRC. Is that the question?

    Mr Chiam See Tong: To bring them into Parliament.

Column: 650



    Mr Wong Kan Seng: The purpose of the GRC is to ensure that Parliament has the representation of all our communities, including the Malays, Indians and other minority communities. So we have in the provision of the law, a minimum of three candidates in a GRC, but no more than six. That has been the practice all along.

    Mr Chiam See Tong: That is the purpose behind the law.

    Mr Wong Kan Seng: That is right. So we have that, and we have achieved the purpose. I do not understand the purpose of his question.

    Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, if I understand the Minister correctly, the delay of the publication of the report of the Electoral Boundaries Review Committee was due to September 11. Can he explain what has September 11 got to do with the preparation of the report of the Electoral Boundaries Review Committee?

    My point about the GRC is that you want to ensure minority candidates. The rationale behind it is that if you have a Chinese candidate and a non-Chinese candidate in a single-seat constituency, the PAP thinks that the Chinese candidate will win against a non-Chinese candidate. So to ensure that the PAP ethnic candidate gets into Parliament, they must have some non-ethnic candidates to come along with them, to bring them into Parliament. My point is: why do you need five other non-ethnic candidates to get the ethnic candidates into Parliament? I think one is enough.

    Mr Wong Kan Seng: That is where I am confused by Mr Chiam's question. Firstly, he did not hear me correctly. I did not say that the publication was due to the September 11 incident.

    Mr Chiam See Tong: You mentioned it.

    Mr Wong Kan Seng: Please check the record. I will repeat it here again for his benefit. What I have said was that the Committee was already doing its work and when it had finished, the report was

Column: 651

published. Because of the September 11 incident as well as the urgency to deal with the economic problems we were facing, the Prime Minister decided on a quick election. That is what I said. The results bore themselves out that the decision was correct and the people gave the PAP a very strong mandate to ensure that we would deal with the problems we are facing now.

    On the question of minority candidates, we all know that in all our constituencies, the racial distribution is quite even. We have explained before that the purpose of the GRC is to ensure that we have minority representation in Parliament and that is why we decided to have GRCs. It has served our purpose that we now have minority candidates in Parliament. Whether we need three, four or five others, it depends on the configuration of the constituency. In some areas, it may be more convenient to group them in three, some maybe four, some maybe five, and some maybe six. From experience, this has borne out to be correct.

    Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, as regards the election deposits, the rationale is that the Government wants to keep out frivolous candidates. The average thinking of Singaporeans is that $13,000 is definitely too high a figure. The non-PAP candidates, most of them, are not well off. In fact, personally, I know that many serious candidates who are in the opposition would have stood for the elections, but for this $13,000. It is not only the candidate himself who has to worry about the $13,000 ---

    Mr Speaker: Mr Chiam, could you ask your supplementary question?

    Mr Chiam See Tong: I am coming to it. The candidate will also have to discuss, being Asians, with members of their family, their wives, and most of them feel that $13,000 is too much, and they do not allow the serious opposition candidate to take part. The other rationale is that the deposit is pegged to the MP's allowance. Why do we not have two categories then? For incumbent Members who want

Column: 652

to stand again, they can take this standard of one month's allowance. But those who are coming in for the first time and who are not MPs, we can reduce it to $3,000. I wonder whether the Minister will allow two categories of deposits.

    Mr Wong Kan Seng: Sir, I do not know about the average thinking of Singaporeans. That is what Mr Chiam said. I am just quoting him. I know of the thinking of average Singaporeans.

    If the candidates think that $13,000 is too much and fear losing their deposit, then they really do not have the confidence that they can even get the support of 1/8 of the voters and they should seriously think again whether they should contest. There are examples of this. Dr Tan Cheng Bock will probably know. The voters there hardly saw that opposition candidate who lost his deposit. Mr Tan Kim Chuang probably did not appeal to the voters in Bukit Timah and, therefore, also lost his deposit. But any serious candidate, anyone with a good platform, should have no problem convincing 1/8 of the electorate to vote for him.

    The idea of two categories of candidates is, I think, a very amazing one. I cannot see the logic behind this suggestion: that new candidates pay less and incumbent candidates or MPs who have retired and want to contest again pay more. Why do we discriminate between different types of candidates? They are all candidates. After all, if he is an elected MP, he is an elected MP. There are no differentials in rights for the MPs if they are elected. So why does the hon. Member want to have different classes of MPs and different classes of candidates?

    Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): Sir, the Minister, in his main answer on the question of rally sites, says that law and order is the main consideration as to why the number of rally sites is reduced and why some rally sites are not even within the constituencies themselves. Does the Minister agree that public rallies during elections are probably the only links that the Opposition could reach out to the

Column: 653

voters effectively? Thus, by reducing the number of rally sites or moving the rally site far away from the constituency itself will reduce the influence that the Opposition could have to persuade the voters to vote for them. Does he also agree that the same argument of law and order applies, ie, would there be a day when we have elections but have no public rallies, because law and order is a concern? And would there then be that, somehow, elections will cause some problem of law and order and, thereby, there shall be no elections because of law and order?

    Mr Wong Kan Seng: I think Mr Low is trying to string A + B = C, which need not necessarily be so in his last question, ie, that because we could have law and order problems, and therefore better not have rallies. I think that is a stretch of the imagination.

    Rallies are not the only ways that candidates reach out to their voters. On that I disagree with him. Rallies are just one of the ways for candidates to reach out to the voters. Reducing Corporate Income Tax

    Reducing the corporate income tax rate from 24.5% to 20% is fundamental to strengthening our competitiveness. The corporate income tax directly reduces the income of a company operating in Singa-pore. When companies compare the relative attractiveness of investing in different countries, the corporate income tax flows straight through to the bottom line. If we set our tax rate too high, we make it harder for companies to make money, expand and create more jobs here.

    Over the last 15 years, the worldwide trend has been towards lower corporate and personal income taxes. In addition, countries often offer generous tax breaks, so that the effective tax rate that their companies pay is much lower than the nominal rate. For example, Germany reduced its corporate income tax rate last year from 40% to 25%; a huge 15 percentage point cut. In the US, the corporate income tax rate is nominally 35%, but various provisions and loopholes reportedly enable some corporations to reduce their effective rate to only 11%. Ireland, one of our competitors in Europe, plans to cut its already low rate to a mere 12.5% next year, supposedly without any tax breaks. Hong Kong's rate is only 16%. These examples show just how fierce the competition is. Unless we keep pace with

our competitors, we will inevitably lose investments and business.

    In the past, we enhanced our competitive position by granting tax incentives that reduced or removed the corporate income tax on certain qualifying companies. For example, Pioneer-status companies enjoy a tax holiday for up to 10 years, while companies granted investment allowances may deduct up to twice their investment expenses from their taxable income. But this strategy has its limitations:

    (iii) Thirdly, our tax incentives are gradually becoming less effective. Our tax treaty partners are seeking to remove tax-sparing provisions from the tax treaties. As a result, the benefits that companies enjoy from our tax incentives are taken away by the other tax jurisdictions, defeating the purpose of the incentive.

    The Government will be rationalising the current system of tax incentives over the next few months. Later on in my speech, I will describe improvements to our tax incentives to encourage the development of certain industries. But we must complement these specific incentives with an across-the-board reduction in the corporate income tax rate, in order to make the tax burden on businesses in general as light as possible, and make it worthwhile for companies to grow and create jobs here.

Raising Goods and Services Tax

    Lowering corporate and personal income taxes will cost the Government a large amount of revenue. If we reduce the tax rates to 20%, in all, the Govern-ment will lose 9% of its annual revenue, or nearly 1.7% of GDP. We cannot afford this loss; we have to make up at least part of it from other sources. That is why we must increase the GST rate from 3% to 5%.

    Some Singaporeans have asked why we cannot simply accept this loss of revenue, and leave the GST rate at 3%. After all, we have been enjoying comfortable surpluses, and should be able to accept smaller, but still large, surpluses in future. The problem is we do not expect large surpluses in future. Growth will be slower and more volatile than before. Revenues will be less buoyant. But demands on the Government to do more and spend more are increasing. Even without any tax cuts, our surpluses are likely to shrink. With the large tax cuts, we face a real risk of ending up with a structural deficit.

    A structural deficit means we will have a deficit in most years, whether the economy is booming or in recession. This will have serious consequences. One key reason the Singapore dollar has been strong, and inflation has been low, is that we have run a prudent fiscal policy. The Government lives within its means, and spends no more than what it receives. If the Govern-ment starts spending beyond what it gets, and borrows or prints money to fund its spending, the Singapore dollar would go down. Inflation would go up. Then, Singaporeans' hard-earned savings would be worth less, including their CPF savings.

    Some argue that it is all right for us to run deficits regularly, because we can always draw on the reserves to make up the shortfall. But that is not what the reserves are for. The reserves are to see us through rainy days, to be used only in extremis, because Singapore produces no oil, timber or gold that we can fall back on. Furthermore, we must not be misled by the fact that all our previous recessions have

been short-lived. We cannot discount the possibility that future recessions will be prolonged and deep in this new environment. If we draw on our reserves routinely, they will soon be gone. In any case, using the reserves requires the consent of the President, who will very likely say "No", and with good justification.

    This is not to say that we will never run deficits. In difficult years we will end up in deficit, as happened last year. But over the whole business cycle, we must aim to maintain a modest surplus. This is only possible if we accumulate surpluses in good years to cover the deficits of lean years. The Government therefore cannot operate on a tax-to-spend basis. Instead, we should build in a margin of savings, especially given the more volatile and uncertain environment in the years ahead.

    A third argument against raising GST is that the Government should instead cut back on its expenditure. We will certainly do our best to be thrifty, especially when times are hard. But our government expenditure is already very lean at 18% of GDP. In contrast, government expenditure in developed countries is typically much higher - 30% to 40% of GDP, double ours. Moreover, hard times are also times when Singaporeans want the Government to respond with generous helping measures. Nevertheless, we will maintain a tight rein on the cost of Government to ensure it stays below 20% of GDP.

Corporate and Personal Income Tax Cuts and GST Increase

    The ERC Sub-Committee recommended that the Government cut corporate and personal income tax rates to 20% in 3 years. For this year, it recommended that the Govern-ment make "significant immediate reductions" in both corporate and personal income tax rates. We have considered carefully the appropriate size of the immediate cuts, and the exact timing of the GST increase. We had to strike a careful balance between the need to make a bold move now, and the need for fiscal prudence in view of the uncertainties in the external environment.

    From YA 2003, I have decided to cut the corporate income tax rate from 24.5%

    Also with effect from YA 2003, the top marginal personal income tax rate will be cut from 26% to 22%, with corresponding cuts in all income bands. This will reduce the tax payable by most taxpayers by 13% to 16%, saving them $620 million every year.

    I have decided to raise the GST rate from 3% to 5% from 1st January 2003. The increase in GST is expected to raise an additional $1.3 billion of tax revenue per year.

Restructuring Corporate Income Tax

    The reduction in corporate income tax will benefit all companies. With the partial exemption of companies' chargeable income since YA 2002, many SMEs already pay less than half the corporate income tax rate. This additional reduction will result in the SMEs paying effective tax rates of between 5.5% and 10%. Besides reducing the rate, we will also restructure the corporate taxation system to introduce two features recommended by the ERC Sub-Committee: group relief and a one-tier tax system.

Group Relief

    Corporations often organise themselves into multiple holding companies, subsidiaries and associates to reflect the structure of their business and to limit liabilities. Sometimes corporations are required by law to set up separate companies for specific purposes. For example, to protect buyers, property developers are required to set up a separate company for each residential development project that they

undertake. However, corporations are not allowed to offset the losses of one company against the taxable profits of another within the same group. Each company in a group pays tax as a separate, stand-alone entity. As a result, setting up separate companies effectively raises the tax rate for the whole group.

    The ERC Sub-Committee has recommended allowing group relief to help reduce the cost of doing business in Singapore. Group relief recognises group companies as a single economic entity by allowing the unutilised losses and capital allowances from one company to offset the profits of a related company in the same group. This is already the case in most developed countries, including the US and the United Kingdom (UK).

    The Government will accept the ERC Sub-Committee's recommen-dation, and introduce a loss-transfer system of group relief with effect from YA 2003. A group consists of a Singapore incorporated parent company and all its Singapore incorporated subsidiaries. Two Singapore incorporated companies could also be members of the same group if one is 75% owned by the other or both are 75% owned by another Singapore incorporated company. Group companies will be allowed to transfer their current year unutilised capital allowances and losses. However, investment allowances and foreign losses may not be transferred.

    The introduction of group relief will lower the tax burden on companies, and encourage more risk-taking and enterprise. It will also help companies during recessions or the early years of new ventures, when they are likely to make losses. Companies which set up subsidiaries for risky ventures will be able to enjoy the limited liability benefit of separate subsidiaries, and still offset these subsidiaries' losses against their own profits.

One-tier Corporate Taxation System

    The ERC Sub-Committee recommended replacing the current full imputation corporate taxation system with a one-tier corporate taxation system. It argued that the current system discourages companies with insufficient dividend franking credits from distributing dividends. Furthermore, the full imputation system is not well adapted to sophisticated business transactions, such as share buy-backs and share borrowing and lending. MOF had to craft complicated tax rules for these transactions to meet concerns about tax avoidance. This increased compliance costs for companies.

    The Government has accepted the Sub-Committee's recommendation. We will introduce the one-tier corporate taxation system with effect from 1st January 2003. Under this system, the tax collected from corporate profits is final. Singapore dividends are exempt. This will greatly simplify our tax code and reduce the cost of compliance and administration for companies. The one-tier system will work in tandem with group relief and the lower corporate income tax rate to make more profits available for distribution as dividends.

During this period, shareholders will still be able to receive dividends with credits attached.

PROTECTION FOR REMITTING MONEY OVERSEAS


    1. Mr Chiam See Tong asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance (a) how his Ministry intends to protect the interest of the public when they remit their money overseas through licensed remittance companies and (b) whether his Ministry will review the existing rules with a view to bring those rules in line with those made for banks.

    Mr Lee Hsien Loong:

    The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) took over the licensing of remittance agents from the Controller of Exchange Control in 1971. When exchange controls were lifted in 1978, remittance agents continued to be licensed by MAS under a new Money-Changing and Remittance Businesses Act (MCRBA). The object of the licensing regime is aimed at excluding undesirable persons from conducting these businesses.

    The remittance industry has grown over the years, but it remains a traditional business, with many small players operating on the basis of relationship and trust. Many are sole proprietorships or family-owned partnerships which cannot institute the same degree of internal controls that larger financial institutions like banks insist upon. Also, remittance houses often use parties such as friends, relatives, employees and unregulated overseas agents instead of banks to deliver funds to designated beneficiaries overseas. Such is the nature of the remittance business. This is why it is difficult to introduce measures to enhance significantly the safety and soundness of remittance houses. Many countries have chosen not to regulate this type of business.

    After careful study, MAS has concluded that introducing new measures or raising the statutory deposit could give the public a false sense of confidence in remittance houses without significantly improving their safety and soundness. In the event of losses, a higher statutory deposit would not guarantee recovery of a significantly larger proportion of the losses. It is therefore important for the public to understand the nature and process of the remittance business, and weigh the benefits and risks of using remittance houses against safer but perhaps less convenient channels provided by banks.

    MAS will continue to conduct background checks on applicants before it grants them remittance licences. MAS will also continue to monitor remittance houses' compliance with existing rules and regulations, and, where justified, will impose fines on errant licensees. In serious cases of irregularities or non-compliance, MAS will consider revoking or not renewing licences. MAS will also refer cases where fraud occurs or is suspected to the Police for investigation.

    Being a cash business, the remittance industry should ideally be required to have control structures similar to banks. As far as is practicable, the MCRBA does require remittance houses to institute some basic control features, eg, audits performed by an external auditor, submission of audited accounts and auditors' findings to MAS, and separation of remittance funds from other accounts of licensees. However, it is not feasible to require these often small, one-man or family-owned operations to adopt most of the important control features found in banks, including corporate governance structures or sophisticated internal control systems.

    For the reasons cited earlier, MAS has, after a review, decided not to amend the MCRBA. Nonetheless, MAS will continue to review its regulations on an ongoing basis.
